questions.text: Which of the following amino acids is likely to aggregate on the surface of a globular protein circulating in the plasma?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lysine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Lysine is a hydrophilic (polar) amino acid with a positively charged side chain. In an aqueous environment like plasma, polar and charged amino acids, such as lysine, preferentially locate on the surface of globular proteins. This positioning allows them to interact with the surrounding water molecules through hydrogen bonds and ionic interactions, stabilizing the protein's structure. Conversely, hydrophobic (nonpolar) amino acids tend to be buried in the interior of the protein to avoid contact with water.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Leucine: Leucine is a hydrophobic (nonpolar) amino acid and would typically be found in the interior of a globular protein.
  • • Option B. Leucine:
  • • Option C. Isoleucine: Isoleucine is also hydrophobic and prefers to reside in the protein's core rather than its surface.
  • • Option C. Isoleucine:
  • • Option D. Valine: Valine is another hydrophobic amino acid, favoring the protein's interior over the aqueous environment.
  • • Option D. Valine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lysine, a hydrophilic and positively charged amino acid, is likely to be found on the surface of globular proteins in aqueous solutions like plasma.

questions.text: Inhibitor A and B are: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Competitive and non-competitive

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Remember that competitive inhibitors increase Km but do not change Vmax, while non-competitive inhibitors decrease Vmax but do not change Km.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about DNA polymerase I? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: It is involved in the creation of Okazaki fragments

options.label: D
options.text: It is the primary enzyme of DNA synthesis

questions.correct_answer: B. It is found in prokaryotes
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It is found in prokaryotes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DNA polymerase I is a critical enzyme found in prokaryotes, involved in DNA replication and repair. While it plays key roles, including the removal of RNA primers from Okazaki fragments, DNA polymerase III is the primary enzyme for DNA synthesis in these organisms

questions.text: Entry of glucose is insulin independent in all of them except: ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Adipose Tissues

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Major Glucose transporters and their function is summarized as:
  • ➤ Major Glucose transporters and their function is summarized as:

questions.text: RNAi acts through? ( INICET May 2021
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Knock down

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Gene knock down is when function of the gene present is suppressed by inhibiting or degrading the target mRNA so that it cannot form its protein. This is also known as post transcriptional gene silencing or RNA interference (RNAi). This is mediated by micro RNA (miRNA) or small interfering RNA (siRNA) which are small 20-27 nucleotides long non-coding RNAs. miRNA based RNAi involves the uses of three enzymes DROSHA, PASHA and DICER.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Knock out: This involves removing or taking a gene out, resulting in a complete loss of gene function.
  • • Option A. Knock out:
  • • Option C. Knock in: This involves inserting a gene into a specific location within the genome.
  • • Option C. Knock in:
  • • Option D. Knock up: This term is not used in the context of gene manipulation.
  • • Option D. Knock up:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ RNA interference (RNAi) acts through gene knock down by suppressing the function of a gene via degradation or inhibition of its target mRNA, preventing protein formation.
  • ➤ Ref- Harper 31 st e/p 346-348
  • ➤ Ref- Harper 31 st e/p 346-348

questions.text: Complex 4 inhibitor is? ( NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cyanide

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cyanide is a potent inhibitor of Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase) in the electron transport chain (ETC). Complex IV is crucial for the final step of the electron transport chain, where it facilitates the transfer of electrons to oxygen, the final electron acceptor, to form water. By inhibiting Complex IV, cyanide prevents the reduction of oxygen, halting ATP production and leading to cellular hypoxia and energy failure.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Carbon Dioxide: Carbon dioxide is not an inhibitor of any of the electron transport chain complexes. It is a byproduct of cellular respiration and does not interfere with the function of the ETC complexes.
  • • Option B. Carbon Dioxide:
  • • Option C. Oligomycin: Oligomycin is an inhibitor of ATP synthase (Complex V) in the electron transport chain. It binds to the F0 subunit of ATP synthase, blocking the proton channel and preventing proton translocation across the inner mitochondrial membrane. This inhibition halts ATP synthesis from ADP and inorganic phosphate.
  • • Option C. Oligomycin:
  • • Option D. Antimycin: Antimycin is an inhibitor of Complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) in the electron transport chain. It binds to the Qi site of cytochrome c reductase, blocking the transfer of electrons from ubiquinol to cytochrome c, disrupting the proton gradient and halting ATP synthesis.
  • • Option D. Antimycin:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inhibitor of ETC complexes
  • ➤ Inhibitor of ETC complexes

References:

  • ↳ Reference : Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 123

questions.text: PCR is used to detect all of the following except? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Aneuploidy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While PCR is highly sensitive for sequence-level changes (SNPs, small deletions) and specific chromosomal breakpoints, it cannot directly detect numerical chromosomal abnormalities (aneuploidy) without specialized modifications. This highlights the importance of choosing appropriate molecular techniques based on the type of genetic alteration being investigated.

questions.text: Banding technique used for dicentric chromosomes: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) C

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Dicentric chromosome is an abnormal chromosome with two centromeres.
  • • C banding : stains heterochromatin which are regions of the chromosomes at or near centromere. So, C banding will be most useful for dicentric chromosomes.
  • • C banding
  • • So, C banding will be most useful for dicentric chromosomes.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. G-banding: G-banding is the most common banding technique and uses Giemsa stain to stain AT-rich regions. It was developed as an alternative to Q-banding due to the cumbersome nature of Q-banding.
  • • Option A. G-banding:
  • • Option B. NOR-banding: NOR-banding (Nucleolar Organizer Region) is used to stain regions associated with nucleolus formation and is not specifically useful for dicentric chromosomes.
  • • Option B. NOR-banding:
  • • Option D. R-banding: R-banding provides a reverse pattern to G-banding, staining GC-rich regions instead of AT-rich regions. It is not specifically useful for identifying dicentric chromosomes.
  • • Option D. R-banding:
  • • Note – Q banding : uses quinacrine dye (first used dye) and stains repetitive AT rich regions.
  • • Note – Q banding

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ C-banding is the preferred technique for identifying dicentric chromosomes as it specifically stains heterochromatin regions at or near the centromere.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Robbins 10th Ed. / page- 262-263, 293

questions.text: Which of the following amino acid is necessary for conversion of nor-epinephrine to epinephrine? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Methionine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methionine is necessary for the conversion of nor-epinephrine to epinephrine.
  • ➤ Norepinephrine is methylated by the enzyme N-methyl transferase (NMT) to epinephrine or adrenaline.
  • ➤ Norepinephrine is methylated by the enzyme N-methyl transferase (NMT) to epinephrine
  • ➤ S-adenosyl methionine (SAM) is the methyl donor . It is mainly produced by adrenal medulla and adrenergic nerve endings. It is stored in chromaffin granules and released into blood.
  • ➤ S-adenosyl methionine (SAM) is the methyl donor

questions.text: During periods of starvation, which of the following tissues primarily utilizes ketone bodies as an energy source? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Brain

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The brain is the primary tissue that utilizes ketone bodies as an energy source during starvation. When glucose levels are low during prolonged fasting or starvation, the brain shifts from relying on glucose to using ketone bodies (acetoacetate and β-hydroxybutyrate) as its main fuel source. The brain can derive up to 75% of its energy requirements from ketone bodies during prolonged starvation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Erythrocytes: Erythrocytes (red blood cells) lack mitochondria and therefore cannot utilize ketone bodies, which require mitochondrial metabolism. They rely exclusively on glucose via glycolysis for their energy needs.
  • • Option A. Erythrocytes:
  • • Option C. Liver: The liver is the main site of ketone body production but cannot utilize ketone bodies itself because it lacks the enzyme thiophorase, which is necessary for ketone body utilization.
  • • Option C. Liver:
  • • Option D. All of the above: This is incorrect because both erythrocytes and liver cannot utilize ketone bodies as explained above.
  • • Option D. All of the above:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During starvation, the brain adapts to use ketone bodies as an alternative fuel source when glucose is limited, while the liver produces but cannot use ketone bodies, and erythrocytes remain dependent on glucose metabolism.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes has the highest catalytic efficiency? ( INICET Nov 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Km of an enzyme = 10 micromole and Kcat = 20 per sec

options.label: B
options.text: Km of an enzyme = 2000 nanomole and Kcat = 50 per sec

options.label: C

questions.correct_answer: C. Km of an enzyme = 2 micromole and Kcat = 200 per sec
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Km of an enzyme = 2 micromole and Kcat = 200 per sec

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Catalytic efficiency, calculated as 𝐾 𝑐𝑎𝑡 /𝐾 𝑚 is maximized with high 𝐾 𝑐𝑎𝑡 ​ and low Km ​.

questions.text: Which of the following types of collagens is involved in wound healing? ( AIIMS May 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Type III

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Properties of Different types of Collagen:

questions.text: Which enzyme is deficient in Von Gierke’s disease: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Glucose-6-phosphatase

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Von Gierke’s disease, also known as Glycogen Storage Disease Type I (GSD I), is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase. This enzyme is crucial for the final step in the gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis pathways, where it catalyzes the conversion of glucose-6-phosphate into glucose, which is then released into the bloodstream. Its deficiency leads to impaired glucose production and subsequent hypoglycemia.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Branching Enzyme: A deficiency in the branching enzyme is associated with Glycogen Storage Disease Type IV (Andersen’s disease), not Von Gierke’s disease. This enzyme is responsible for adding branches to the growing glycogen molecule, and its deficiency leads to abnormal glycogen structure.
  • • Option A. Branching Enzyme:
  • • Option C. Debranching Enzyme: A deficiency in the debranching enzyme characterizes Glycogen Storage Disease Type III (Cori’s disease), not Von Gierke’s disease. This enzyme is involved in the breakdown of glycogen, particularly in removing the branches from glycogen during glycogenolysis.
  • • Option C. Debranching Enzyme:
  • • Option D. Myophosphorylase: Myophosphorylase deficiency is seen in Glycogen Storage Disease Type V (McArdle’s disease). This enzyme is involved in glycogen breakdown in muscle tissue, and its deficiency leads to muscle-related symptoms, especially during exercise.
  • • Option D. Myophosphorylase:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Von Gierke’s disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I) is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase, leading to impaired glucose production from gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis, and resulting in hypoglycemia.
  • ➤ C/F of this disease includes glycogen accumulation in liver and renal tubule cells, hypoglycaemia, lactic academia, ketosis and hyperlipidemia.
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 174
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 174

questions.text: dd-NTPs in Sanger’s Sequencing technique uses? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Termination of polymerase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dideoxy nucleotides are nucleotides in which O from 2’ and 3’ position of sugar is absent. These nucleotides, if inserted in the growing DNA chains will cause termination of polymerization as DNA polymerase will not be able to perform catalyzation of formation of Phosphodiester bond. This form the basis for a DNA sequencing technique know as Sanger DNA sequencing aka chain termination method.
  • ➤ termination of polymerization

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 439

questions.text: Which one of the following assertions is correct? (NEET PG 2015)

options.label: A
options.text: Every acidic amino acid is essential.

options.label: B
options.text: Every basic amino acid is essential.

options.label: C
options.text: Every neutral amino acid is essential.

options.label: D
options.text: None of the statements are correct.

questions.correct_answer: D. None of the statements are correct.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) None of the statements are correct

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The classification of amino acids as essential or non-essential is independent of their acidic, basic, or neutral properties. Essential amino acids cannot be synthesized in sufficient amounts by humans and must be obtained from the diet.
  • • Looking at specific examples:
  • • Acidic amino acids (aspartate and glutamate) are non-essential Basic amino acids include arginine (semi-essential), lysine (essential), and histidine (semi-essential) Neutral amino acids include both essential (valine, leucine, isoleucine) and non-essential (alanine, glycine) amino acids
  • • Acidic amino acids (aspartate and glutamate) are non-essential
  • • Basic amino acids include arginine (semi-essential), lysine (essential), and histidine (semi-essential)
  • • Neutral amino acids include both essential (valine, leucine, isoleucine) and non-essential (alanine, glycine) amino acids
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Every acidic amino acid is essential: This is incorrect. Acidic amino acids (glutamate and aspartate) are both non-essential as they can be synthesized from TCA cycle intermediates.
  • • Option A. Every acidic amino acid is essential:
  • • Option B. Every basic amino acid is essential : This is incorrect. While lysine is essential, arginine is semi-essential (some amount can be made in the body), and histidine is semi-essential (essential in children but not in adults).
  • • Option B. Every basic amino acid is essential
  • • Option C. Every neutral amino acid is essential : This is incorrect. Many neutral amino acids like alanine, serine, glycine, and proline are non-essential, while others like leucine and isoleucine are essential.
  • • Option C. Every neutral amino acid is essential

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amino acid classification by chemical property (acidic, basic, neutral) has no correlation with their nutritional classification (essential vs non-essential), with both essential and non-essential amino acids occurring across all chemical categories.

questions.text: The illustration below shows alternative splicing of a gene which has intron segments 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5. It yields two products A and B, by the action of different promoters. You are provided with the promoters W, X, Y, and Z, each of which binds to a different segment as shown below and acts in the marked direction. Which of the following promoters will you use to get product A? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. W Y

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • A promoter is a region of DNA upstream of a gene where relevant proteins bind to initiate
  • • transcription of that gene. In the case of this question, product A is formed by including specific
  • • segments and excluding others through the process of alternative splicing.
  • • Sequence A consists of segments 1, 3, 4, and 5. Promoter W Required for segment 1. Promoter Y Required for segments 3, 4, and 5. Segment 2 is excluded during alternative splicing.
  • • Sequence A consists of segments 1, 3, 4, and 5. Promoter W Required for segment 1. Promoter Y Required for segments 3, 4, and 5. Segment 2 is excluded during alternative splicing.
  • • Promoter W Required for segment 1. Promoter Y Required for segments 3, 4, and 5. Segment 2 is excluded during alternative splicing.
  • • Promoter W Required for segment 1.
  • • Promoter Y Required for segments 3, 4, and 5.
  • • Segment 2 is excluded during alternative splicing.
  • • Thus, the combination of Promoters W and Y will result in the production of sequence A by including
  • • the correct segments and excluding segment 2.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option a (W, X, Y) : This combination Required Promoter X, for segment 2, but it is unnecessary since W and Y alone are sufficient to yield product A. Option b (W, Z) : Promoter Z does not include segments 3, making this option incorrect for generating product A. Option c (WX) : Promoters W and X are insufficient because they do not include segments 3, 4, and 5, which are essential for product A.
  • • Option a (W, X, Y) : This combination Required Promoter X, for segment 2, but it is unnecessary since W and Y alone are sufficient to yield product A.
  • • Option a (W, X, Y) : This combination Required Promoter X, for segment 2, but it
  • • Option a (W, X, Y)
  • • is unnecessary since W and Y alone are sufficient to yield product A.
  • • Option b (W, Z) : Promoter Z does not include segments 3, making this option incorrect for generating product A.
  • • Option b (W, Z)
  • • Option c (WX) : Promoters W and X are insufficient because they do not include segments 3, 4, and 5, which are essential for product A.
  • • Option c (WX)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A promoter is a region of DNA upstream of a gene where relevant proteins bind to initiate
  • ➤ transcription of that gene.
  • ➤ Using promoters W, Y will yield product A by including segments 1, 3, 4, and 5 and removing segment 2 through alternative splicing.

questions.text: In which of the genetic material, Number of Adenine will not be equal to that of Thymine:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) HIV

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) is a retrovirus with RNA as its genetic material. In RNA, adenine pairs with uracil. So, the number of adenine will not be equal to that of thymine.

questions.text: Which of the following is deficient in a patient with phenylketonuria with normal phenylalanine hydroxylase levels? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dihydrobiopterin reductase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In non-classical phenylketonuria, the deficiency is in dihydrobiopterin reductase, not phenylalanine hydroxylase.

questions.text: Which amino acid is not used for synthesis of hormones? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Glycine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tyrosine, phenylalanine, and tryptophan are all aromatic amino acids that serve as building blocks for the synthesis of various hormones.

questions.text: Vitamin B12 is found maximum in: ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Animal products

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin B12 is naturally present in foods of animal origin, including fish, meat, poultry, eggs, and dairy products. Hence, vegetarians usually are prone to develop vitamin b12 deficiency. Strict vegetarians (vegans) are at risk of developing B12 deficiency.
  • ➤ foods of animal origin, including fish, meat, poultry, eggs, and dairy products.
  • ➤ Strict vegetarians (vegans) are at risk of developing B12 deficiency.

questions.text: An infant presented to the OPD with a history of vomiting and poor feeding. Musty odor is present in the baby's sweat and urine. Guthrie test was done and it was found to be positive. All are true regarding this disease except? ( AIIMS May 2018)

options.label: B
options.text: White patch of hair due to tryptophan deficiency

questions.correct_answer: B. White patch of hair due to tryptophan deficiency
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) White patch of hair due to tryptophan deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PKU is characterized by a deficiency in phenylalanine hydroxylase, leading to elevated phenylalanine levels and its metabolites, which cause neurological symptoms, hypopigmentation, and a musty odor. Early detection and dietary management are crucial for preventing severe mental retardation.

questions.text: A bodybuilder starts eating raw eggs for protein. He starts to develop fatigue on moderate exercise. The doctor prescribes a vitamin. Which enzyme is deficient in him? ( AIIMS May 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pyruvate Carboxylase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Eating raw eggs can lead to biotin deficiency due to avidin binding, resulting in a deficiency of pyruvate carboxylase. This enzyme deficiency impairs gluconeogenesis, causing fatigue during exercise. Supplementing biotin can correct the deficiency and alleviate symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following site does the restriction enzyme act when RFLP is used in-order to identify the five different species of staphylococci in a surgical ICU? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) GATATC- CTATAG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In RFLP, restriction enzymes recognize and cut at palindromic sequences in DNA. The palindromic sequence GATATC-CTATAG is a correct recognition site for these enzymes, making it crucial for identifying different species, such as staphylococci in a surgical ICU.

questions.text: Composition of lactulose: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Galactose + Fructose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sucrose = Glucose + Fructose Trehalose = Glucose + Glucose Maltose = Glucose + Glucose Lactose = Glucose + Galactose Lactulose = Galactose + Fructose
  • ➤ Sucrose = Glucose + Fructose
  • ➤ Trehalose = Glucose + Glucose
  • ➤ Maltose = Glucose + Glucose
  • ➤ Lactose = Glucose + Galactose
  • ➤ Lactulose = Galactose + Fructose

questions.text: Wobble hypothesis is due to which property of the codon?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Degeneracy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The wobble hypothesis is primarily due to the degeneracy of the genetic code, allowing multiple codons to code for the same amino acid, with variation in the third (wobble) position of the codon.
  • ➤ Wobble bases
  • ➤ Wobble bases
  • ➤ 3rd base of the codon on mRNA and 1 st base of anticodon on tRNA in 5’ to 3’ direction are wobble positions.
  • ➤ Wobble hypothesis says that for binding between bases present in these positions, some imprecision is allowed. i.e. one base in anticodon can bind with various bases of codon. This is also called as degeneracy of codon i.e. There is more than one codon for one amino acid. So, Wobble hypothesis is due to degeneracy of codons.

questions.text: Which is not a product of heme catabolism? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Aminolaevulinic acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aminolaevulinic acid is a precursor in the synthesis of heme, not a product of its catabolism.

questions.text: An infant present with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. Which of the following is accumulated in the brain in cerebrohepatorenal syndrome? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Long chain fatty acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zellweger syndrome or Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome is due to defective oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA ). Peroxisomal enzymes are produced; but their entry into peroxisome is denied. This leads to insufficient oxidation of VLCFA. Accumulation of VLCFA in CNS causes profound neurologic impairment and death in childhood.
  • ➤ Zellweger syndrome or Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome is due to defective oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA
  • ➤ Accumulation of VLCFA in CNS causes profound neurologic impairment

questions.text: A patient with glycogen storage disease has impaired glucose sensing in pancreatic beta cells. Which glucose transporter defect best explains this? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Glut 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand that:
  • ➤ GLUT2's unique properties (low affinity, high capacity) make it ideal for glucose sensing It's essential for beta cell function and glucose-stimulated insulin secretion This differs from GLUT4 which responds to insulin rather than sensing glucose Different GLUT transporters have specific tissue distributions and functions based on their kinetic properties
  • ➤ GLUT2's unique properties (low affinity, high capacity) make it ideal for glucose sensing
  • ➤ It's essential for beta cell function and glucose-stimulated insulin secretion
  • ➤ This differs from GLUT4 which responds to insulin rather than sensing glucose
  • ➤ Different GLUT transporters have specific tissue distributions and functions based on their kinetic properties

questions.text: A patient presented with bilateral symmetrical hyperpigmented scaly lesions on sun-exposed areas, along with diarrhea and dementia. What is the diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pellagra

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand that:
  • ➤ Pellagra presents with the classic triad of dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia The dermatitis is photosensitive and symmetrical This helps differentiate it from other nutritional deficiency dermatoses The systemic involvement (GI and neurological) is key to diagnosis
  • ➤ Pellagra presents with the classic triad of dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia
  • ➤ The dermatitis is photosensitive and symmetrical
  • ➤ This helps differentiate it from other nutritional deficiency dermatoses
  • ➤ The systemic involvement (GI and neurological) is key to diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following is the etiology of the Werner syndrome with premature aging? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: B
options.text: Short telomere with damaged DNA and loss of helicase

questions.correct_answer: B. Short telomere with damaged DNA and loss of helicase
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Short telomere with damaged DNA and loss of helicase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Werner syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by premature aging. It is caused by mutations in the WRN gene, which encodes a protein called Werner syndrome ATP-dependent helicase (WRN). The WRN protein is involved in DNA repair, maintenance of genome stability, and telomere maintenance. One of the other functions of this protein is DNA helicase.
  • ➤ In Werner syndrome, there is a loss of function of the WRN protein, leading to problems with DNA repair and telomere maintenance. Telomeres are the protective caps at the ends of chromosomes, and they shorten with each cell division. In Werner syndrome, there is accelerated telomere shortening, and this contributes to premature aging. There is also increased risk of cancer.
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s 31st/e pg. 370
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s 31st/e pg. 370

questions.text: Methyl tetrahydrofolate accumulation and functional deficiency of folate is seen in the deficiency of: ( INICET May 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vit B12

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand the metabolic consequences of vitamin deficiencies, medical students should recognize that the functional deficiency of folate, characterized by the accumulation of methyl tetrahydrofolate, is primarily seen in vitamin B12 deficiency, making it important to distinguish between the two deficiencies in clinical practice.
  • ➤ Deficiency of Vitamin B12 leads to accumulation of methyl THF. Free THF becomes deficient (Folate Trap) and as THF is functional form of folate it is also known as functional deficiency of folate.
  • ➤ Ref - Harper 31 st e/p 536
  • ➤ Ref - Harper 31 st e/p 536

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent kidney stones. The microscopic examination of the urine specimen is shown below. Which of the following is not seen in the urine of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cysteine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cystinuria: Cystinuria is one of the inborn errors of metabolism included in the Garrod’s tetrad. It is an autosomal recessive condition.
  • ➤ Cystinuria is one of the inborn errors of metabolism included in the Garrod’s tetrad.
  • ➤ an autosomal recessive
  • ➤ The disorder is attributed to the deficiency in transport of amino acids Signs and symptoms include:
  • ➤ Signs and symptoms include:
  • ➤ Abnormal excretion of cystine and to a lesser extent lysine, ornithine and arginine. Hence the condition is also called Cystine-lysinuria . Crystalluria and calculi formation . In acidic pH, cystine crystals are formed in urine Obstructive uropathy, which may lead to renal insufficiency Cyanide-Nitroprusside Test is a screening test . Urine is made alkaline with ammonium hydroxide and sodium cyanide is added. Cystine, if present, is reduced to cysteine. Then add sodium nitroprusside to get a magenta-red colored complex. Specific aminoaciduria may be confirmed by chromatography. Treatment is to increase urinary volume by increasing fluid intake . Solubility of cystine is increased by alkalinization of urine by giving sodium bicarbonate.
  • ➤ Abnormal excretion of cystine and to a lesser extent lysine, ornithine and arginine. Hence the condition is also called Cystine-lysinuria .
  • ➤ Cystine-lysinuria
  • ➤ Crystalluria and calculi formation . In acidic pH, cystine crystals are formed in urine
  • ➤ . In acidic pH, cystine crystals are formed in urine
  • ➤ Obstructive uropathy, which may lead to renal insufficiency
  • ➤ Cyanide-Nitroprusside Test is a screening test . Urine is made alkaline with ammonium hydroxide and sodium cyanide is added. Cystine, if present, is reduced to cysteine. Then add sodium nitroprusside to get a magenta-red colored complex. Specific aminoaciduria may be confirmed by chromatography.
  • ➤ Cyanide-Nitroprusside Test is a screening test
  • ➤ Treatment is to increase urinary volume by increasing fluid intake . Solubility of cystine is increased by alkalinization of urine by giving sodium bicarbonate.

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: D. RT-PCR followed by Real time PCR
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) RTPCR followed by Real time PCR

questions.text: Diarrhoea by cholera toxin involves which receptors: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) GM1 ganglioside receptor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cholera toxin, produced by Vibrio cholerae, causes diarrhea by binding to the GM1 ganglioside receptor on the surface of intestinal epithelial cells. The binding of cholera toxin to GM1 facilitates its entry into the cells, where it exerts its toxic effects by activating adenylate cyclase and increasing intracellular cyclic AMP (cAMP). Elevated cAMP levels lead to the secretion of chloride ions and water into the intestinal lumen, resulting in watery diarrhea characteristic of cholera.
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 212
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 212

questions.text: A patient has liver damage. His eyes examination showed the given picture. Patient also had neurological manifestations. Which factor is responsible for his disease? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Copper

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The described clinical picture is highly suggestive of Wilson's disease, a genetic disorder of copper metabolism. In Wilson's disease, there is an accumulation of copper in various tissues, including the liver and brain, leading to liver damage and neurological symptoms. The eye examination often reveals Kayser-Fleischer rings, a characteristic sign involving copper deposition in the cornea.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Galactose: While disorders in galactose metabolism, such as galactosemia, can cause liver damage, they do not typically present with the specific eye findings or the same neurological manifestations described in the scenario. Galactosemia usually presents in infancy with symptoms like oil drop cataract, failure to thrive, jaundice, and feeding difficulties.
  • • Option B. Galactose:
  • • Option C. Mannose: Mannose metabolism disorders are rare and do not typically present with liver damage, neurological symptoms, and eye changes as described. These disorders often have different clinical manifestations, including developmental delay and immune dysfunction.
  • • Option C. Mannose:
  • • Option D. Glucose: While diabetes (a disorder of glucose metabolism) can lead to liver damage and may have ocular manifestations (like diabetic retinopathy), it does not typically present with Kayser-Fleischer rings or the described neurological symptoms.
  • • Option D. Glucose:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kayser-Fleischer ring shown in the image occurs in Wilson disease. This disease is caused by mutations in a copper-binding ATPase which leads to copper storage in the eye (Kayser-Fleischer ring), liver (hepatitis and cirrhosis) and brain (psychosis).
  • ➤ Kayser-Fleischer ring shown in the image occurs in Wilson disease.
  • ➤ This disease is caused by mutations in a copper-binding ATPase which leads to copper storage in the eye (Kayser-Fleischer ring), liver (hepatitis and cirrhosis) and brain (psychosis).
  • ➤ copper storage

questions.text: Liver produces KB but cannot use KB due to absence of which enzyme: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The liver plays a crucial role in ketone body metabolism. During periods of prolonged fasting or low carbohydrate intake, the liver produces ketone bodies (acetoacetate and β-hydroxybutyrate) through a process called ketogenesis. These ketone bodies are then released into the bloodstream and can be used as an alternative fuel source by various tissues, including the brain, heart, and skeletal muscles.

questions.text: Child presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be Zellweger syndrome. Which among the following accumulates in brain in this condition? ( AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.explanation:

questions.text: Which of the following deficiency causes xerophthalmia and follicular hyperkeratosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Vitamin A deficiency is well known to cause a range of clinical manifestations, primarily affecting the eyes and skin. Key signs and symptoms include:
  • • Vitamin A deficiency is well known to cause a range of clinical manifestations, primarily affecting the eyes and skin. Key signs and symptoms include:
  • • Xerophthalmia : This condition includes dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea, which can progress to keratomalacia and lead to blindness if untreated.
  • • Xerophthalmia : This condition includes dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea, which can progress to keratomalacia and lead to blindness if untreated.
  • • Xerophthalmia
  • • Follicular hyperkeratosis : This is characterized by excessive keratin deposits in hair follicles, leading to rough, bumpy skin.
  • • Follicular hyperkeratosis : This is characterized by excessive keratin deposits in hair follicles, leading to rough, bumpy skin.
  • • Follicular hyperkeratosis
  • • Vitamin A is crucial for maintaining healthy vision, immune function, and skin integrity. Its deficiency can result in:
  • • Vitamin A is crucial for maintaining healthy vision, immune function, and skin integrity. Its deficiency can result in:
  • • Night blindness Immunosuppression : Leading to increased susceptibility to infections. Skin ulceration and corneal ulceration Atrophy of urinary and respiratory tract epithelium , increasing the risk of infections in these areas.
  • • Night blindness
  • • Night blindness
  • • Immunosuppression : Leading to increased susceptibility to infections.
  • • Immunosuppression
  • • Skin ulceration and corneal ulceration
  • • Skin ulceration and corneal ulceration
  • • Atrophy of urinary and respiratory tract epithelium , increasing the risk of infections in these areas.
  • • Atrophy of urinary and respiratory tract epithelium
  • • Other Options:

  • • Option B. Niacin
  • • Option C. Biotin : Deficiency can cause dermatitis, alopecia, and neurological symptoms.
  • • Option C. Biotin
  • • Option D. Vitamin B6 : Deficiency can cause anemia, dermatitis, and neurological symptoms.
  • • Option D. Vitamin B6

questions.text: A 35-year-old Farmer on maize diet with diarrhoea, dementia, and dermatitis. Which Vitamin is deficient in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Niacin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The major protein of Maize, “Zein” lacks tryptophan which is required for Niacin biosynthesis. 60 mg of tryptophan gives 1 mg of Niacin in the body. So, pellagra is more common when maize is the staple diet due to decreased synthesis of Niacin. Pellagra is characterized by 3Ds i.e. diarrhoea, dementia and dermatitis. Death and delirium and depression can also occur.
  • ➤ Pellagra can also be caused due to Isoniazid therapy as isoniazid inhibits PLP (B6) formation which in turn is required for Niacin synthesis. Vitamin B2 is also required for Niacin synthesis, so, a deficiency either of B2 or B6 or both can cause pellagra.
  • ➤ Thiamine (B1) deficiency leads to Beri-Beri. CNS and CVS are affected in dry Beri-Beri and wet Beri-Beri respectively.
  • ➤ Main symptoms of Riboflavin deficiency are Cheilosis, Glossitis and Corneal vascularization.
  • ➤ Pyridoxine deficiency cause anemia (microcytic, hypochromic) and seizures in infants.
  • ➤ Ref -Harper 31 st e/pg. 534-535
  • ➤ Ref -Harper 31 st e/pg. 534-535

questions.text: In a preterm baby with respiratory distress syndrome, which of the following lipid would be deficient?( NEET PG 2020 )
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dipalmitoyl phosphatidyl choline

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ RDS occurs when there is not enough surfactant in the lungs. Surfactant is a liquid made by the lungs that keeps the airways (alveoli) open. Pulmonary surfactant is a surface-active lipoprotein complex (phospholipoprotein) formed by type II alveolar cells. The proteins and lipids that make up the surfactant have both hydrophilic and hydrophobic regions. By adsorbing to the air-water interface of alveoli, with hydrophilic head groups in the water and the hydrophobic tails facing towards the air, the main lipid component of surfactant is dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC).
  • ➤ Ref- Harper 31st ed pg – 234
  • ➤ Ref- Harper 31st ed pg – 234

questions.text: This multienzyme complex converts Pyruvate to Acetyl CoA. Identify E1 and E2: (NEET PG 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase

options.label: B
options.text: E1: Pyruvate Decarboxylase E2: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase

options.label: C
options.text: E1: Pyruvate carboxylase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase

options.label: D
options.text: E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase

questions.correct_answer: A. E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • The provided images depict the components and functioning of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, a key multienzyme complex in the metabolic pathway that converts pyruvate into acetyl-CoA, an essential step linking glycolysis to the citric acid cycle. This complex requires vitamins B1, B2, B3, B5, and lipoic acid as cofactors.
  • • Table: Components of PDH complex and their roles
  • • Table: Components of PDH complex and their roles
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Pyruvate Decarboxylase and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase: Incorrect as Pyruvate Decarboxylase is not involved in the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA in this context, and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase is the E3 component of the complex.
  • • Option B. Pyruvate Decarboxylase and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase:
  • • Option C. Pyruvate carboxylase and Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase: Incorrect because Pyruvate carboxylase is involved in a different metabolic pathway (gluconeogenesis), not in the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA.
  • • Option C. Pyruvate carboxylase and Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase:
  • • Option D. Pyruvate dehydrogenase and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase: Incorrect as the second enzyme is E3 in this complex, not E2.
  • • Option D. Pyruvate dehydrogenase and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ref-Harper 31 st e/pg. 162
  • ➤ Ref-Harper 31 st e/pg. 162

questions.text: The significance of HMP shunt are all except? ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Utilizes ribose

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The Hexose Monophosphate (HMP) shunt, also known as the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP), has several significant roles:
  • • The Hexose Monophosphate (HMP) shunt, also known as the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP), has several significant roles:
  • • Source of NADPH: The HMP shunt produces NADPH in its oxidative phase. NADPH is essential for various biosynthetic reactions, including fatty acid synthesis and maintaining the reduced state of glutathione in red blood cells. Source of ribose 5 phosphate: At the end of the oxidative phase, ribulose 5-phosphate is produced, which can be further converted into ribose 5-phosphate. Ribose 5-phosphate is a crucial precursor for the synthesis of nucleotides and nucleic acids. Source of acetyl CoA: One of the end products of the HMP shunt is glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate, which can enter glycolysis. Through glycolysis, it can eventually form pyruvate, which can be converted into acetyl CoA in the presence of oxygen.
  • • Source of NADPH: The HMP shunt produces NADPH in its oxidative phase. NADPH is essential for various biosynthetic reactions, including fatty acid synthesis and maintaining the reduced state of glutathione in red blood cells.
  • • Source of NADPH:
  • • Source of ribose 5 phosphate: At the end of the oxidative phase, ribulose 5-phosphate is produced, which can be further converted into ribose 5-phosphate. Ribose 5-phosphate is a crucial precursor for the synthesis of nucleotides and nucleic acids.
  • • Source of ribose 5 phosphate:
  • • Source of acetyl CoA: One of the end products of the HMP shunt is glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate, which can enter glycolysis. Through glycolysis, it can eventually form pyruvate, which can be converted into acetyl CoA in the presence of oxygen.
  • • Source of acetyl CoA:
  • • Other Option:
  • • Other Option:
  • • Option D. Utilizes ribose: This statement is incorrect as the HMP shunt primarily produces ribose 5-phosphate rather than utilizing it. Ribose 5-phosphate is a significant product of this pathway and is used in the synthesis of nucleotides and nucleic acids.
  • • Option D. Utilizes ribose:
  • • The overall reaction of the HMP shunt can be summarized as:
  • • The overall reaction of the HMP shunt can be summarized as:
  • • 3G-6-P+6NADP+→2G-6-P+Glyceraldehyde-3-P+3CO2+6NADPH

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The HMP shunt is significant for producing NADPH and ribose 5-phosphate and indirectly contributing to the formation of acetyl CoA, but it does not utilize ribose.

questions.text: The anterior incisors of a child with white patches turned brown following over supplementation of: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Fluorine in water

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The description of white patches turning brown on the anterior incisors of a child is indicative of dental fluorosis. This condition occurs due to excessive fluoride intake, particularly during the years when teeth are developing. Fluoride is beneficial in small amounts for dental health, but excessive exposure, often due to high levels in drinking water or overuse of fluoride supplements, can lead to fluorosis, which manifests as mottling and discoloration of teeth.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Chlorine in Water: While chlorine is used to purify water, it does not cause dental fluorosis, which is characterized by changes in the color and structure of teeth. Chlorine at levels used in water treatment does not typically result in dental discoloration.
  • • Option A. Chlorine in Water:
  • • Option C. Vitamin A: While excessive Vitamin A intake can lead to toxicity with a variety of symptoms, it does not cause dental fluorosis. Vitamin A toxicity typically presents with symptoms such as skin changes, vision disturbances, and bone pain, but not with changes in tooth color.
  • • Option C. Vitamin A:
  • • Option D. Riboflavin: Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) is not associated with dental discoloration. Deficiency of riboflavin can lead to mouth and lip sores, but its excess does not result in changes similar to fluorosis.
  • • Option D. Riboflavin:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fluoride prevents caries, as topical application of fluoride will result in a fluorapatite layer on the enamel, which protects enamel from the decay by acid. The safe limit of fluorine is about 1 ppm in water. Fluoride level >>2 ppm causes chronic intestinal upset, gastroenteritis, loss of appetite and loss of weight. Level >>5 ppm causes mottling of enamel, stratification and discoloration of teeth. A level >>>20 ppm is toxic and causes alternate areas of osteoporosis and osteosclerosis with brittle bones known as fluorosis.
  • ➤ Fluoride prevents caries, as topical application of fluoride will result in a fluorapatite layer on the enamel, which protects enamel from the decay by acid.
  • ➤ The safe limit of fluorine is about 1 ppm in water.
  • ➤ Fluoride level >>2 ppm causes chronic intestinal upset, gastroenteritis, loss of appetite and loss of weight.
  • ➤ Level >>5 ppm causes mottling of enamel, stratification and discoloration of teeth.
  • ➤ A level >>>20 ppm is toxic and causes alternate areas of osteoporosis and osteosclerosis with brittle bones known as fluorosis.
  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of Medical biochemistry 3rd edition Page no. 416
  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of Medical biochemistry 3rd edition Page no. 416

questions.text: A paint factory worker working since 20 years complains of joint pain, insomnia, fatigue, constipation, headache. He is found to have anemia. Enzyme affected is? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ferrochelatase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The reference of paint factory worker indicates that it is a case of lead poisoning. Lead affects two enzymes of Heme synthesis pathway:
  • ➤ PBG synthase Ferrochelatase (last enzyme of heme synthesis and adds Fe to its substrate)
  • ➤ PBG synthase
  • ➤ Ferrochelatase (last enzyme of heme synthesis and adds Fe to its substrate)
  • ➤ The defect in any of these enzymes will lead to decrease in haem synthesis resulting in anemia. So, the answer in this case is Ferrochelatase.

References:

questions.text: Brunt sugar smell of urine is due to the defect of? ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.correct_answer: D. Branched chain keto acid dehydrogenase
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Branched chain keto acid dehydrogenase

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Burnt sugar-like odour is a characteristic feature of Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) which occurs due to the inherited deficiency of branched chain Keto-acid dehydrogenase/decarboxylase. It results in a defect in oxidative phosphorylation and catabolism of branched-chain amino acids (BCAA) Valine/Isoleucine/leucine. As a result, these amino acids are excreted in urine. There is also mental retardation.
  • • Burnt sugar-like odour is a characteristic feature of Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) which occurs due to the inherited deficiency of branched chain Keto-acid dehydrogenase/decarboxylase.
  • • It results in a defect in oxidative phosphorylation and catabolism of branched-chain amino acids (BCAA) Valine/Isoleucine/leucine. As a result, these amino acids are excreted in urine. There is also mental retardation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Phenylalanine hydroxylase: Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase leads to phenylketonuria (PKU), which is characterized by a mousy or musty odor due to the accumulation of phenylalanine and its metabolites.
  • • Option A. Phenylalanine hydroxylase:
  • • Option B. Isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase: Deficiency of isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase causes isovaleric acidemia, which is associated with a rancid, cheesy, or sweaty feet odor due to the accumulation of isovaleric acid.
  • • Option B. Isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase:
  • • Option C. Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase: Deficiency of fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase leads to tyrosinemia type I, which is characterized by a boiled cabbage or rotten mushrooms odor due to the accumulation of tyrosine and its metabolites.
  • • Option C. Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the 1000 Genomes Project? (Twisted PYQ)

options.label: A
options.text: Aimed to catalog human genetic variation

options.label: D
options.text: Created a public database of variants

questions.correct_answer: B. Included populations from single continent
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Included populations from single continent

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand key features of the 1000 Genomes Project:
  • ➤ It was a comprehensive effort to catalog global human genetic variation Included diverse populations from multiple continents Used modern sequencing technologies Made data publicly available Differed from the Human Genome Project by focusing on population-level variation rather than creating a single reference genome
  • ➤ It was a comprehensive effort to catalog global human genetic variation
  • ➤ Included diverse populations from multiple continents
  • ➤ Used modern sequencing technologies
  • ➤ Made data publicly available
  • ➤ Differed from the Human Genome Project by focusing on population-level variation rather than creating a single reference genome

questions.text: What is true about the Hayflick limit? ( INICET May 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Human cells can divide a finite number of times only

options.label: B
options.text: Free radical oxidation level is unrestricted

options.label: D
options.text: RNA polymerase can function for a finite number of times only

questions.correct_answer: A. Human cells can divide a finite number of times only
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Human cells can divide a finite number of times only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Hayflick limit describes the finite number of times that normal human cells can divide before they become senescent, primarily due to telomere shortening.
